Title: HTMX, Raku and Pico CSS
Description: This post is kind of part 3, coming off last week’s thrilling episode. I am a simple sole, I want to reduce the cognitive load in my web projects. The general idea is to go back to the halcyo…

Title: Samuel Pass Blog
Description: For the past thirteen months, I've been building a portfolio of trading strategies from start to finish (from research to production trading). I was a researcher, developer, and trader. This job ended just a few days ago, but the search for alpha must live on! Typically, whenever I thought of a trading idea in the past, I'd relay it to the person I worked with. Given that I don't have any infrastructure to trade with at the moment and my dataset mainly consists of Yahoo Finance, I decided to share my thoughts with the world so that someone with access to infrastructure can have something fun to think about. So, here it goes.

Title: You're Only Young Once But You Can Be Stupid Forever
Description:
STAY STUPID FOREVER, BY HERE NOW!


OPTION 1

If the people in charge are smart, I want to be stupid.

Title: Top-N queries: fetch only the first N rows
Description: LIMIT, TOP, or FETCH FIRST abort an SQL query after finding a number of rows. Use the right index.

Title: Exploiting CI / CD Pipelines for fun and profit – Razz Security Blog
Description: In today’s world of fast-paced development and continuous integration, security vulnerabilities can be easy to overlook. Recently, I discovered a severe exploit chain, starting from a publicly exposed .git directory, which led to a full server takeover. This blog will walk through the chain of events, outlining how each weak point compounded the issue.

Title: Synchronous vs Asynchronous vs Concurrent vs Parallel  - What is the difference and why does it matter?

Title: Minimal cross-platform graphics
Description: Exploring how to use 2D graphics in various desktop operating systems, the old-school way. In this part we learn how to create an empty window under Linux, macOS and Windows.

Title: Are We Living in a Simulation?
Description: I posit that it’s statistically unlikely for an engineer to get a job working on a system that isn’t either imaginary or legacy software. There is no middle ground.
